name: 'King of the Hill' - 'Hank's Problem' Quiz | Television | 10 Questions

questions.text: After several failed attempts to 'make', Hank Hill's family begins to notice his problems with constipation.  What does Peggy provide Hank a plate of for breakfast one morning in order to fight his irregularity problem?
questions.explanation:
Oat bran muffins.

	Peggy also offers Hank Hill some 'Metamucil', a fiber drink.  Bobby suggests his father consume the muffins by saying, 'You should eat those, they help you make!'  Hank proceeds to feed the oat bran muffins to Lady Bird.

questions.text: News of Hank's constipation problems spreads quickly throughout the neighborhood.  Who is the first neighbor to address Hank about this very personal dilemma?
questions.explanation:
Bill.

	Bill gently asks Hank about his constipation, which he has learned about from Dale through Nancy.  There are no secrets in the Hill neighborhood, everyone also learns about Hank's narrow urethra and abnormally small buttocks as well in different episodes.

questions.text: Who goes so far as to announce that Hank has problems with constipation on local television?
questions.explanation:
Nancy.

	Nancy Gribble is a weatherperson for the local television station, and she takes some time out from her busy telecast to wish Hank Hill good luck with his struggle against irregularity.

questions.text: Another of Peggy's tricks is to put chocolate laxative syrup on Hank's ice cream.  Does Hank consume the entire bowl of ice cream?
questions.explanation:
No.

	As soon as Hank learns about Peggy's trick, he leaves the ice cream on the table, hardly having taken a bite.  He claims that Peggy is trying to 'drug' him.  Bobby happily eats the ice cream after Hank leaves, assuring that he will be regular for the next several days.

questions.text: One evening, Peggy has a terrible nightmare about Hank's death.  Which famous figure of medicine appears in Peggy's frightening dream?
questions.explanation:
C. Everett Koop

	Former U.S. Surgeon General C. Everett Koop appears on television that evening, talking specifically about constipation.  That night, Peggy has a dream that she is at Hank's funeral.  C. Everett Koop is one of the featured speakers at the funeral. Cotton is one of the pallbearers, but he is so short that he hangs with both hands on Hank's coffin.  Dale exclaims during the proceedings that 'It should have been Bill!'

questions.text: After an awakened and frightened Peggy confronts Hank about her scary dream, he finally agrees to go to see a doctor.  At the doctor's office, Dr. Morley looks over Hank's chart and mistakenly believes Hank is suffering from which 'sickness'?
questions.explanation:
Consumption.

	Dr. Morley sees 'consumption' (an old term for Tuberculosis) and is briefly alarmed.  Hank straightens things out by explaining that it is actually constipation that is the problem.

questions.text: While in Dr. Morley's office, Hank agrees to undergo a certain procedure that will help elucidate the source of his problems.  What is this procedure called?
questions.explanation:
Sigmoidoscopy.

	Hank's sigmoidoscopy becomes even more embarrassing when a medical student named Tasha comes in to assist Dr. Morley.  While everyone else seems quite pleased with the proceedings, Hank is rather mortified.

questions.text: Dr. Morley talks to the Hill family after the procedure about the various options that they have.  In so doing, the doctor claims that the intestines are very long, and if fully stretched out, could claim a distance as long as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The circumference of Earth.

	In actuality, the intestines are nowhere near this long.  Hank is quite skeptical, and rightly so, when the doctor makes this claim.  Hank claims correctly that food would have to travel awfully fast to make its way through intestines that long.

questions.text: After visiting the doctor, Hank continues in his attempts to eat more healthily.  The Hill family visits a store called 'Soy to the World' in order to pick up some items made completely from soy beans.  Which of these is offered to them in this store?
questions.explanation:
Not Dogs.

	After the shopkeeper fails to convince the Hills to purchase some 'not dogs', made from tofu, he offers them some 'faux fu', a tofu substitute.  Hank asks if there's anything in the store that actually tastes good, a question that completely stymies the shopkeeper.

questions.text: Hank becomes completely desperate in his attempts to battle his constipation.  He even tries a method Dale describes to him.  What is the only item involved in Dale's 'prescription' that we become privy to?
questions.explanation:
Bacon grease.

	We never actually hear how Dale's concoction is made, but we can rest assured that, whatever it is, it certainly will not work.   What ends up working for Hank is to just go back to his usual lifestyle and stop worrying so much about his constipation.  At the end of the show, he finally is able to have a successful bowel movement.  Joy returns to Arlen! Thank you for playing this quiz, I hope you have enjoyed it and I wish you continued regularity.
